Article.ArticleTitle: Particulate matter and ozone might trigger deaths from chronic ischemic heart disease.

AbstractText: To study the association between short-term exposure to air pollutants and mortality of Chronic Ischemic Heart Disease (CIHD).

Using a case-crossover design, we investigated 148,443 CIHD deaths from 2015 to 2020 in Jiangsu Province, China. Exposure to six ambient pollutants, including PM<sub>10</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, NO<sub>2</sub>, CO, SO<sub>2</sub>, and O<sub>3,</sub> was assessed by extracting daily concentrations from validated 10 km × 10 km pollutant grids at each subject's residential address. A conditional logistic regression approach was used to explore the exposure-response relationship with adjustment for temperature and relative humidity. We calculated the Population Attributable Fractions (PAFs) and the attributable deaths number of CIHD.

An increase of 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> in PM<sub>10</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposure was associated with a 1.16% (95% CI: 0.85-1.48%) and 1.80% (1.36-2.24%) increase in CIHD mortality, respectively. A threshold value of 123 µg/m<sup>3</sup> was identified for the association between O<sub>3</sub> exposure and CIHD mortality. Controlling for PM<sub>2.5</sub>, each increase of 10 µg/m<sup>3</sup> in O<sub>3</sub> (>threshold) was statistically significantly associated with a 0.94% (0.19-1.71%) increase in CIHD mortality, however there was no association between NO<sub>2</sub>, SO<sub>2</sub>, CO exposure and CIHD mortality. Reducing PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> to the WHO air quality guidelines would prevent 6.16% (95% CI: 4.70-7.58%), 4.30% (3.18-5.43%) and 1.29% (0.48-4.20%) of CIHD deaths, respectively. During the warm season, mortality and PAFs of CIHD associated with PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, and O<sub>3</sub> were significantly higher.

Short-term exposure to ambient PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10,</sub> and O<sub>3</sub> might trigger deaths from CIHD. These findings indicate that the premature deaths of CIHD patients can be alleviated by reducing exposure to polluted air.
